questions.question: What does npm stand for?
questions.description: Choose the correct answer.
questions.hint: Think about the role of npm in managing Node.js packages.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! npm stands for Node Package Manager.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. npm stands for Node Package Manager.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. npm stands for Node Package Manager.

questions.question: How do you install a package globally using npm?
questions.description: Choose the correct answer.
questions.hint: Consider the command structure for global installations.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm install <package-name> -g'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm install <package-name> -g'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! This is the correct command to install a package globally using npm.

questions.question: What command is used to initialize a new npm package?
questions.description: Choose the correct answer to initialize a new project with npm.
questions.hint: Think about the first step you take when starting a new Node.js project.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm start' is used to run a script named 'start' in your package.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm init' is used to initialize a new npm package.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. There is no 'npm create' command for initializing a new npm package.

questions.question: What file is commonly used to manage project dependencies in an npm package?
questions.description: Choose the correct file for managing dependencies in an npm project.
questions.hint: Consider the file where you list your project's dependencies.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'package.json' is the file used to manage project dependencies in an npm package.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct file is 'package.json'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct file is 'package.json'.

questions.question: How do you uninstall a global npm package?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to uninstall a globally installed npm package.
questions.hint: Think about the opposite action of installing a global package.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm uninstall <package-name> -g' is used to uninstall a global npm package.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm uninstall <package-name> -g'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm uninstall <package-name> -g'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to show information about a specific package?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to get details about a particular npm package.
questions.hint: Consider how you might inspect a package before installing it.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm view <package-name>' shows information about a specific package.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm view <package-name>'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm view <package-name>'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to run scripts defined in the package.json file?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to execute scripts specified in the package.json file.
questions.hint: Think about how you execute custom scripts defined in your project.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm run <script-name>'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm start' runs the 'start' script, but it's not a generic command for all scripts.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm run <script-name>' is used to run scripts defined in the package.json file.

questions.question: Which npm command is used to update all packages to their latest version?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to update all packages to their latest versions.
questions.hint: Consider how you might keep your project's dependencies up to date.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm upgrade' updates all packages to their latest version.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm upgrade'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm update' updates packages but may not bring them to their latest version.

questions.question: What does the --save flag do when installing a package using npm?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the --save flag when installing npm packages.
questions.hint: Consider the historical significance of the --save flag in npm installations.

options.label: A
options.description: It saves the package as a development dependency.
options.explanation: Incorrect. '--save' is no longer necessary for npm versions 5.0.0 and above.

options.label: B
options.description: It saves the package as a production dependency.
options.explanation: Incorrect. '--save' is no longer necessary for npm versions 5.0.0 and above.

options.label: C
options.description: It used to save the package as a dependency, but it's not required in npm 5.0.0 and above.
options.explanation: Correct! '--save' used to be required in earlier npm versions to save the package as a dependency, but it's not necessary in npm 5.0.0 and above.

questions.question: How do you check the installed version of npm on your system?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to check the installed version of npm.
questions.hint: Think about how you might query the version of npm installed on your machine.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm version' is used for managing package versions within a project.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm -v' or 'npm --version' displays the installed version of npm on your system.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm info' is used to get information about a specific package, not the npm version.

questions.question: What command is used to install a specific version of an npm package?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install a specific version of a package.
questions.hint: Consider how you might specify a version when installing a package.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name>@<version>'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install <package-name>@<version>' installs a specific version of a package.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name>@<version>'.

questions.question: What does the --save-dev flag do when installing a package using npm?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the --save-dev flag.
questions.hint: Consider the purpose of development dependencies in a project.

options.label: A
options.description: It saves the package as a production dependency.
options.explanation: Incorrect. '--save-dev' is used to save packages as development dependencies.

options.label: B
options.description: It saves the package as a dependency without specifying the version.
options.explanation: Incorrect. '--save-dev' is specifically for development dependencies.

options.label: C
options.description: It saves the package as a development dependency.
options.explanation: Correct! '--save-dev' is used to save packages as development dependencies.

questions.question: What npm command is used to list installed packages and their versions?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to display a list of installed packages.
questions.hint: Consider how you might inspect the current state of your project's dependencies.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm show' is used to display package metadata, not the installed packages.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm list' shows a tree of installed packages and their versions.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm info' is used to get information about a specific package.

questions.question: What npm command is used to update a package to its latest version?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to update a package to its latest version.
questions.hint: Think about how you might update a specific package in your project.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm update' may not bring the package to its latest version.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install <package-name>@latest' updates a package to its latest version.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm upgrade' updates all packages, not a specific one.

questions.question: What npm command is used to uninstall a package from a project?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to remove a package from your project.
questions.hint: Consider how you might remove a package you no longer need.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm remove <package-name>' uninstalls a package from your project.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm uninstall' is used to uninstall packages, but it may leave them in your package.json file.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm delete' is not a valid command for uninstalling packages.

questions.question: What npm command is used to run a script defined in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to execute a custom script from your package.json file.
questions.hint: Consider how you might execute custom scripts defined in your project.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm run-script <script-name>' executes a script defined in package.json.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm run-script <script-name>'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm start' runs the 'start' script, but it's not a generic command for all scripts.

questions.question: How can you see the details of a locally installed npm package?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to view details of a package installed in your project.
questions.hint: Think about how you might inspect the details of a locally installed package.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm show <package-name>' displays details of a locally installed package.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm info' is used to get information about a specific package, not the locally installed ones.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm view' is used to view information about a package, but 'npm show' is more appropriate for locally installed packages.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install packages listed in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install dependencies specified in your project's package.json file.
questions.hint: Consider how you might install the dependencies listed in your project.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm i' is a shorthand for 'npm install', installing packages listed in package.json.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm add' is used for adding new dependencies, not installing existing ones.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. There is no 'npm install-packages' command. The correct command is 'npm install' or 'npm i'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install a package and save it as a development dependency?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install a package as a development dependency.
questions.hint: Consider how you might install packages specifically for development purposes.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install <package-name> --save-dev' installs the package and saves it as a development dependency.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is '--save-dev', not '--dev'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is '--save-dev', not '--dev'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install packages globally?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install packages globally.
questions.hint: Consider how you might install packages so they are accessible across different projects.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm install <package-name> -g'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install -g <package-name>' installs a package globally.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm install <package-name> -g'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install packages and save them as development dependencies?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install packages and save them as development dependencies.
questions.hint: Consider how you might install packages specifically for development purposes.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name> --save-dev'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install --save-dev <package-name>' installs the package and saves it as a development dependency.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is '--save-dev', not '--dev'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to update all packages, including their dependencies, to their latest versions?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to update all packages, including their dependencies, to their latest versions.
questions.hint: Consider how you might ensure all packages in your project are up to date.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm update', but it may not bring all packages to their latest versions.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm upgrade', but specifying '--latest' is not necessary.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm upgrade' updates all packages, including their dependencies, to their latest versions.

questions.question: What npm command is used to uninstall a development dependency?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to uninstall a package that is a development dependency.
questions.hint: Think about how you might remove a package that was installed for development purposes.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm uninstall <package-name> --save-dev'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm uninstall --save-dev <package-name>' uninstalls a development dependency.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm uninstall <package-name> --save-dev'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to check for outdated packages in your project?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to check for outdated packages in your project.
questions.hint: Consider how you might identify packages that have newer versions available.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm outdated' checks for outdated packages in your project.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm check-updates' is a third-party tool for checking for updates, but it's not an npm command.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. There is no 'npm update-check' command. The correct command is 'npm outdated'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install packages from a specific registry?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install packages from a registry other than the default.
questions.hint: Consider how you might specify a different registry when installing packages.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install <package-name> --registry <registry-url>' installs a package from a specific registry.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm set-registry' is used to set the default registry, not for installing packages from a specific registry.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name> --registry <registry-url>'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to create a package.json file interactively?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to create a package.json file interactively.
questions.hint: Think about how you might initialize a new project and answer questions about its configuration.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm init' creates a package.json file, but it's not interactive.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. There is no 'npm generate' command for creating a package.json file interactively.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm init --interactive' creates a package.json file interactively by asking questions about your project.

questions.question: What npm command is used to display a list of globally installed packages?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to show a list of packages installed globally on your system.
questions.hint: Consider how you might inspect globally installed packages.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm list -g' displays a list of globally installed packages.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm show -g' is used to display metadata about a globally installed package, not the list of all packages.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm list -g' for displaying a list of globally installed packages.

questions.question: What npm command is used to clean the cache of installed packages?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to clean the npm cache.
questions.hint: Consider how you might free up disk space by removing cached packages.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm cache clean' removes all data from the cache.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm cache clean'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm cache clean'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install a package and save it as a peer dependency?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install a package and save it as a peer dependency.
questions.hint: Consider how you might specify a peer dependency when installing a package.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name> --peer'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install <package-name> --peer' installs the package and saves it as a peer dependency.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name> --peer'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install packages from a package-lock.json file?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install packages based on the dependencies listed in package-lock.json.
questions.hint: Consider how you might install packages according to a lock file.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm ci' to install packages based on package-lock.json.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm ci' to install packages based on package-lock.json.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm ci' installs packages based on the dependencies listed in package-lock.json.

questions.question: What npm command is used to publish a package to the npm registry?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to publish a package to the npm registry.
questions.hint: Consider how you might share your package with others on the npm registry.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm share' is not a valid command for publishing a package.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm publish' is used to publish a package to the npm registry.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm upload' is not a valid command for publishing a package.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the prepublish script in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the prepublish script in package.json.
questions.hint: Consider when the prepublish script is executed in the npm package lifecycle.

options.label: A
options.description: It runs before the package is packed and published.
options.explanation: Correct! The prepublish script is executed before the package is packed and published.

options.label: B
options.description: It runs after the package is published to the npm registry.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The prepublish script runs before the package is packed and published.

options.label: C
options.description: It runs during the installation of the package.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The prepublish script runs before the package is packed and published, not during installation.

questions.question: What npm command is used to run a script defined as a lifecycle event?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to execute a script defined as a lifecycle event in package.json.
questions.hint: Consider how you might run scripts defined in the npm package lifecycle.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm start' runs the 'start' script, but it's not a generic command for all lifecycle events.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm run-script <script-name>' executes a script defined as a lifecycle event in package.json.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm run-script <script-name>'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to view the contents of a specific package in the npm registry?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to inspect the contents of a package in the npm registry.
questions.hint: Consider how you might gather information about a package without installing it.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm show <package-name>' displays information about a specific package in the npm registry.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm inspect' is used for inspecting the contents of the current project, not a package in the registry.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'npm view' is used to view information about a package, but 'npm show' is more appropriate for the registry.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install a package globally and save it as a development dependency?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install a package globally and save it as a development dependency.
questions.hint: Consider how you might install global packages for development purposes.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name> -g --save-dev'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name> -g --save-dev'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install -g <package-name>' installs a package globally and saves it as a development dependency.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'files' field in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the 'files' field in package.json.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'files' field affects what gets included when the package is packed or published.

options.label: A
options.description: It specifies the list of files to be included when the package is packed or published.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'files' field in package.json specifies the list of files to be included when the package is packed or published.

options.label: B
options.description: It defines the files that should be ignored by version control systems.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'files' field is specific to what gets included when the package is packed or published, not version control.

options.label: C
options.description: It indicates the entry point file for the package.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'files' field is not used to specify the entry point file; it's for listing files to be included.

questions.question: What npm command is used to update a package to its latest version?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to update a package to its latest version.
questions.hint: Consider how you might ensure a package is using the latest available version.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm install <package-name>@latest' to update to the latest version.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name>@latest' to update to the latest version.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install <package-name>@latest' installs the latest version of a package.

questions.question: What npm command is used to create a new package version and update the package.json and package-lock.json files?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to create a new package version and update the package.json and package-lock.json files.
questions.hint: Consider how you might bump the version of your package and update related files.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. There is no 'npm bump' command. The correct command is 'npm version'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm version' is used to create a new package version and update package.json and package-lock.json.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm version' for updating the version and related files.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'shrinkwrap' feature in npm?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the 'shrinkwrap' feature in npm.
questions.hint: Consider how 'shrinkwrap' helps ensure consistent installations across different environments.

options.label: A
options.description: It is used to create a tarball of the package for offline installations.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'shrinkwrap' feature is not related to creating tarballs for offline installations.

options.label: B
options.description: It locks down the versions of a package's dependencies to ensure consistent installations.
options.explanation: Correct! 'shrinkwrap' is used to lock down the versions of a package's dependencies for consistent installations.

options.label: C
options.description: It compresses the files of the package to reduce its size.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'shrinkwrap' feature is not about compressing package files but about version consistency.

questions.question: What npm command is used to uninstall a global package?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to uninstall a package that was installed globally.
questions.hint: Consider how you might remove a global package from your system.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm uninstall -g <package-name>' uninstalls a globally installed package.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm uninstall -g <package-name>'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm uninstall -g <package-name>'.

questions.question: What npm command is used to run a script in the context of the current project?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to execute a script within the context of the current project.
questions.hint: Consider how you might run a script defined in the current project's package.json.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm run <script-name>' for executing scripts in the project context.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm run <script-name>' for executing scripts in the project context.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm run <script-name>' executes a script within the context of the current project.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'preinstall' script in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the 'preinstall' script in package.json.
questions.hint: Consider when the 'preinstall' script is executed in the npm package lifecycle.

options.label: A
options.description: It runs before the package is packed and published.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'preinstall' script runs before the package is installed, not packed or published.

options.label: B
options.description: It runs before the 'install' script when the package is installed.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'preinstall' script runs before the 'install' script when the package is installed.

options.label: C
options.description: It runs after the package is installed.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'preinstall' script runs before the 'install' script when the package is installed.

questions.question: What npm command is used to check for security vulnerabilities in your project's dependencies?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to scan for security vulnerabilities in your project's dependencies.
questions.hint: Consider how you might ensure the security of your project by checking for vulnerabilities.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm audit' checks for security vulnerabilities in your project's dependencies.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm audit' for checking security vulnerabilities.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm audit' for checking security vulnerabilities.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'prepare' script in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the 'prepare' script in package.json.
questions.hint: Consider when the 'prepare' script is executed in the npm package lifecycle.

options.label: A
options.description: It runs before the package is packed and published.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'prepare' script runs after the package is installed but before it is packed or published.

options.label: B
options.description: It runs after the package is packed and published.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'prepare' script runs after the package is installed but before it is packed or published.

options.label: C
options.description: It runs after the package is installed but before it is packed or published.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'prepare' script runs after the package is installed but before it is packed or published.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install a specific version of a package?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install a package at a specific version.
questions.hint: Consider how you might specify the version of a package to install.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install <package-name>@<version>' installs the specified version of a package.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name>@<version>' to install a specific version.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install <package-name>@<version>' to install a specific version.

questions.question: What npm command is used to list the scripts defined in the package.json file?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to display a list of scripts defined in package.json.
questions.hint: Consider how you might inspect the available scripts in a project.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm run' to execute scripts, not 'npm scripts'.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm run' to execute scripts, not 'npm list-scripts'.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm run' displays a list of available scripts defined in package.json.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'files' field in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the 'files' field in package.json.
questions.hint: Consider how the 'files' field affects what gets included when the package is packed or published.

options.label: A
options.description: It specifies the list of files to be included when the package is packed or published.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'files' field in package.json specifies the list of files to be included when the package is packed or published.

options.label: B
options.description: It defines the files that should be ignored by version control systems.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'files' field is specific to what gets included when the package is packed or published, not version control.

options.label: C
options.description: It indicates the entry point file for the package.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'files' field is not used to specify the entry point file; it's for listing files to be included.

questions.question: What npm command is used to update all packages to their latest versions based on the version range specified in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to update all packages to their latest versions based on the version range.
questions.hint: Consider how you might update packages while respecting the version constraints in package.json.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm install' to update packages based on the version range in package.json.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct command is 'npm install' to update packages based on the version range in package.json.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install' updates packages to their latest versions based on the version range specified in package.json.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'postpublish' script in package.json?
questions.description: Choose the correct explanation for the 'postpublish' script in package.json.
questions.hint: Consider when the 'postpublish' script is executed in the npm package lifecycle.

options.label: A
options.description: It runs before the package is packed and published.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'postpublish' script runs after the package is packed and published.

options.label: B
options.description: It runs after the 'publish' script when the package is published.
options.explanation: Correct! The 'postpublish' script runs after the 'publish' script when the package is published.

options.label: C
options.description: It runs before the package is published to the npm registry.
options.explanation: Incorrect. The 'postpublish' script runs after the package is packed and published.

questions.question: What npm command is used to install packages from a specific registry?
questions.description: Choose the correct command to install packages from a registry other than the default npm registry.
questions.hint: Consider how you might specify a different registry when installing packages.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct! 'npm install --registry=<registry-url>' installs packages from the specified registry.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install --registry=<registry-url>' for specifying a registry.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. The correct syntax is 'npm install --registry=<registry-url>' for specifying a registry.
